result.markdown:
--- title: "Lecture [04a] Activity" --- ![](../../img/programmer_2780E3.svg){.hero} ## Question 1 The following table summarizes the season information for the eight seasons of AMC's *Breaking Bad* show. a) Tidy up this data and save it to a tibble. Decide for yourself how to handle season 5 (should it be a single observation or two?). For the first and last aired dates, just store the year as a number. b) Save the tibble you created to a CSV file named "breaking_bad.csv". ![](../../img/breaking_bad_wikipedia.png)

Click here for the answer key
**Part (a)** Version with one observation for the season five parts ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) season <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) episodes <- c(7, 13, 13, 13, 16) first_air <- c(2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012) last_air <- c(2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2013) network <- "AMC" breaking_bad <- tibble(season, episodes, first_air, last_air, network) breaking_bad ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 × 5 season episodes first_air last_air network 1 1 7 2008 2008 AMC 2 2 13 2009 2009 AMC 3 3 13 2010 2010 AMC 4 4 13 2011 2011 AMC 5 5 16 2012 2013 AMC ``` ::: ::: Version with two separate observations for the season five parts ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) season <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5.1, 5.2) episodes <- c(7, 13, 13, 13, 8, 8) first_air <- c(2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013) last_air <- c(2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013) network <- "AMC" breaking_bad <- tibble(season, episodes, first_air, last_air, network) breaking_bad ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 5 season episodes first_air last_air network 1 1 7 2008 2008 AMC 2 2 13 2009 2009 AMC 3 3 13 2010 2010 AMC 4 4 13 2011 2011 AMC 5 5.1 8 2012 2012 AMC 6 5.2 8 2013 2013 AMC ``` ::: ::: **Part (b)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} write_csv(breaking_bad, "breaking_bad.csv") ``` :::

## Question 2 Load the `starwars` dataset, which is included in \{tidyverse\}. This means that, as long as the package is loaded in your session/document, you can just type its name (`starwars`) and R will be able to access it as if you had imported it. a) Use an R command to calculate how many variables and observations are in this tibble. b) Use an R command to extract the `height` vector from this tibble.

Click here for the answer key
**Part (a)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) dim(starwars) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 87 14 ``` ::: ::: There are 87 rows and 14 columns. **Part (b)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} starwars$height ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 172 167 96 202 150 178 165 97 183 182 188 180 228 180 173 175 170 180 66 [20] 170 183 200 190 177 175 180 150 NA 88 160 193 191 170 196 224 206 183 137 [39] 112 183 163 175 180 178 94 122 163 188 198 196 171 184 188 264 188 196 185 [58] 157 183 183 170 166 165 193 191 183 168 198 229 213 167 79 96 193 191 178 [77] 216 234 188 178 206 NA NA NA NA NA 165 ``` ::: :::

## Question 3 a) Download the `kaggle_cereal.csv` file from Canvas and save it to your class Project folder. b) Use \{tidyverse\} to import this file into R as a tibble named `cereal`, using an argument to make the missing values (coded as `"missing"`) into `NA`s.

Click here for the answer key
**Part (b)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cereal <- read_csv("../../data/kaggle_cereal.csv", na = "missing") cereal ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 77 × 8 name mfr type calories sodium carbo sugars rating 1 100% Bran Nabisco cold 70 130 5 6 68.4 2 100% Natural Bran Quaker O… cold 120 15 8 8 34.0 3 All-Bran Kelloggs cold 70 260 7 5 59.4 4 All-Bran with Extra Fiber Kelloggs cold 50 140 8 0 93.7 5 Almond Delight Ralston … cold 110 200 14 8 34.4 6 Apple Cinnamon Cheerios General … cold 110 180 10.5 10 29.5 7 Apple Jacks Kelloggs cold 110 125 11 14 33.2 8 Basic 4 General … cold 130 210 18 8 37.0 9 Bran Chex Ralston … cold 90 200 15 6 49.1 10 Bran Flakes Post cold 90 210 13 5 53.3 # ℹ 67 more rows ``` ::: :::

--- *Note that there is no need to turn in Activities. These are just for practice!*
